Award.AwardTitle: Quality Understanding and Engagement for Students and Teachers on Computational Thinking (QUEST CT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project "Quality Understanding and Engagement for Students and Teachers on Computational Thinking" (QUEST CT) was submitted to is STEM+C (STEM + Computing Partnerships) which is a program that challenges STEM educators to approach education with a new lens - integrating Computational Thinking as part of traditional STEM disciplinary learning. The significance of the QUEST CT project is that it will (1) develop a model for teacher professional development to support integration of Computational Thinking into STEM classroom activities, and (2) broaden the participation of students from traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM and computing through the combination of formal and informal learning experiences. The project will directly impact more than 1000 students as 18 project teachers implement Computational Thinking-integrated science lessons into classroom activities over two years. The Computational Thinking lessons developed and field tested by teachers will contribute to the need for exemplary resources that effectively integrate Computational Thinking concepts into existing STEM classroom content and will be available to all educators.

The goals of QUEST CT are: to increase teacher knowledge and ability to integrate Computational Thinking as defined by ISTE (International Society for Technology in Education) and CSTA (Computer Science Teachers Association) into fifth and sixth grade science lessons and activities; and to increase student STEM interest and understanding of Computational Thinking concepts in the context of learning science. With support from various school districts, the project will engage 18 fifth and sixth grade teachers in professional development including a summer academy, coached lesson development, and professional learning communities. Each year, more than 500 students from three school districts that reflect varying levels of diversity will be involved in the project through formal classroom activities and informal events such as summer camp, after school clubs and family nights. Ongoing mentoring and support from the project leadership will allow close monitoring of project progress. Graduate and undergraduate computer science students will provide technical support for teachers as they implement Computational Thinking learning experiences. The project uses a combination of two educational research approaches: exploratory research and design and development research. The fundamental education problem addressed is to design and implement an intervention that replaces the disjointed efforts to integrate Computational Thinking into STEM within K-12.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The QUEST CT project focused on professional development for teachers in grades 3 - 6 to increase their knowledge and ability to design and implement classroom learning that supports student development of Computational Thinking (CT) skills. The target grades were selected because self-contained classrooms provide maximum contact time between teachers and their students, affording more flexibility in schedule and potential for sustained impact. 

The project engaged a cohort of 18 teachers in a 2-year program with an iterative design and development research process to track teacher adoption of CT. Each summer, teachers participated in a weeklong summer academy for intensive professional development. Working in teams, teachers collaboratively designed CT integrated science lessons during the academy and field tested them during a student summer camp directly following the academy. This model allowed teachers to observe, reflect, and refine the curriculum and instructional strategies they learned. During the school year, the project provided additional opportunities for teachers to collaboratively create, field test, refine, and share CT-integrated lessons during a Lesson Study experience. 

The project examined how formal school-based activities coupled with informal community-based events could provide a rich, STEM-based CT learning environment. The formal school-based interventions were conducted through classroom lessons designed and delivered by teachers participating in the project professional development. The community based events involved project teachers, their students, and community partners, university computer science mentors and project families. The informal, out-of-school interventions included summer camps, afterschool clubs, and family nights, which provided additional support for project students, targeting traditionally underrepresented student groups in STEM. Over the two year period, about 1,000 students benefited from the formal interventions and over 300 participated in the informal interventions.

The project worked with teachers and students from a diverse socio-economic range so that the project learning and findings could identify varying needs among these groups and the results are applicable to a broader audience. Participating teachers reported that they teach student cohorts ranging from 21 students to 35 students, with a mean size of 28 students, and a median size of 31 students. All classrooms have between 41 and 61% girls. Classrooms vary greatly in their composition of English Language Learner (ELL) students; some classrooms have no ELL students, while others have ELL majorities. Overall, approximately 38% of students do not speak English at home. Teachers reported on the number of students who were one grade level or more behind in reading. The mean percentage of students reported by teachers to be behind in reading was 31% and a median of 23%. Pre- and post-survey showed that students whose first language was not English made greater gains in CT understanding and skills and female student gains were similar to male students.

Based on the success of the 2-year, iterative design and development research process, the project designed an effective 2-day dissemination workshop to include exemplary CT-integrated lessons and pedagogy, including strategies for teachers to encourage student development of CT problem solving skills. The workshop was delivered in 5 states and supported over 150 teachers from 20 school districts. During the pandemic, the project transformed the in-person dissemination workshop to a multi-module virtual workshop that included both synchronous and asynchronous components. Twenty-two teachers from 13 districts in 7 states participated in the virtual workshops
